Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Story: I was halfway through mixing cement when my phone buzzed with a message from my stepmother: “It’s time. Everyone’s waiting for you to start the ceremony.” My hands shook, dust clinging to my skin, as the site-wide evacuation alarm blared overhead. The foreman’s voice cut through the chaos, “Drop everything! Muster point, now!” My heart pounded. At home, I was the step-child expected to honor my late father by leading the family’s annual remembrance—something my stepmother insisted would keep us together. But here, on the construction site, I was just another laborer, expected to follow safety protocols without question. If I left now, I’d let down my family, maybe even fracture the fragile peace we’d built. If I stayed, I’d be risking my job and the safety of my team. The weight of both worlds pressed on me, each demanding something I couldn’t give to the other. I stood frozen, torn between the echoing alarm and the silent pull of family tradition, unable to move in either direction.
